dimensions: trimmed close to plate: 11.1 x 17.5 cm. (4 3/8 x 6 7/8 in.)
creditline: Bequest of Junius S. Morgan, Class of 1888

texts.textentryhtml: Junius S. Morgan (1867–1932); bequeathed to the Princeton University Art Museum, 1932
texts.remarks: as per Jun P. Nakamura & Laura M. Giles

texts.textentryhtml: William Esdaile [1758-1837, Lugt 2617]. Julian Marshall [1836-1903, Lugt 1496]. Francis Seymour Haden [1818-1910, Lugt 1227]; sale of his collection, London, June 15-19, 1891, lot 128. Junius S. Morgan [1867-1932, Lugt 1536]; bequeathed to Princeton University Art Museum, 1932.

As with many of Claude Lorrain’s paintings, his landscape etchings derive inspiration from the countryside around Rome, where he settled in 1627. In this imaginary scene, a herdsman drives his flock through the shallow waters of a ford, followed by two women, one of whom has set down her basket and is removing her stockings. The inclusion of rustic figures in an idyllic setting identifies both etchings as examples of the pastoral genre in seventeenth-century landscape painting, which evoked the legendary unspoiled wilderness of Greek Arcadia, celebrated since antiquity by Virgil and subsequent poets as a place where humankind lived in harmony with nature.

bibliography.boilertext: Lino Mannocci, The Etchings of Claude Lorrain (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1988).
bibliography.citation:
Lino Mannocci, The Etchings of Claude Lorrain (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1988).

, n. 12
